com.leacox.motif

Class Motif

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.leacox.motif.Motif

  • public final class Motif
extends Object
    Motif provides a fluent API for Scala-like pattern matching.

    For more information and examples see documentation on match(Object).

    Author:
    John Leacox

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      static <T> FluentMatching<T> match(T value)
      Begins pattern matching on the specified value.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Method Detail

      • match

        public static <T> FluentMatching<T> match(T value)
        Begins pattern matching on the specified value.

        This is the entry point into the fluent pattern matching API. References should not be created to the returned objects from the fluent API. The only reference that should be created is from the result of getMatch().

        Motif provides many built in matching cases, including:

        • Primitives
        • Optional
        • Lists
        • TypeOf (instanceof)
        • Tuple1
        • Tuple2
        • Tuple3
        • Case1 classes
        • Case2 classes
        • Case3 classes

        In addition the matching case API is extremely extensible. All that is needed to create a new matching case is to implement one of the ExtractorN (e.g. Extractor1) and FieldExtractor for your type, and then create a new instance of DecomposableMatchBuilderN with the field extractor for your type and the args to match on. The easiest way to do this is to create a static method that can be imported like OptionalCases#some(MatchesAny).

        The following are some basic pattern matching examples: 

         

 // Matching on Optional
 Optional<Person> personOpt = getPerson();
 match(personOpt)
     .when(some(any())).then(person -> doStuff(person))
     .when(none()).then(() -> System.out.println("Person not found"))
     .doMatch();
 
 
         

 // Fizzbuzz (Matching on Tuples)
 IntStream.range(0, 101).forEach(
     n -> System.out.println(
         match(Tuple2.of(n % 3, n % 5))
             .when(tuple2(eq(0), eq(0))).get(() -> "FizzBuzz")
             .when(tuple2(eq(0), any())).get(y -> "Fizz")
             .when(tuple2(any(), eq(0))).get(x -> "Buzz")
             .orElse(String.valueOf(n))
             .getMatch()
     )
 );
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the value
        Parameters:
        value - the value the match on
        Returns:
        FluentMatching object used to fluently build pattern matches. Do not create a reference to the returned object.
